So, until the fetus can live by itself, it has to be considered part of what it is living off of (in this case the mother). The fact is, your arm is part of you because it lives off of you, it can't live by itself can it? Same thing with a fetus, it has to be considered part of you because it can't survive on its own until after the sixth month of development.

That's the thing though - different texts are intended to be read in different ways. Each form of literature, you could say, is a game with certain rules of participation between the author (making the story) and the potential reader (receiving the story). The Bible falls into that special category of literature called "Theology" or "Moral Epistemology" - a statement of the various objects and rules that constitute the game called "Christian Morality".
 
 The interesting thing about the Bible is that it is written aphoristically, rather than literally - trying to cite by a combination of exposition and example instances of good behaviour or attitudes. But what's captivating about it is its use of colloquialistic, rather than poetic, metaphors in order to get the point across. It's a religion for everyone, rather than just for priests (or academics).
 
 However as an example of deeply meditative thought, the Bible pales in comparison to Plato's Republic, the Tao-te-Ching, Kant's Metaphysics of Morals, let alone Wittgenstein's Philosophical Investigations. Like every other meditative-text there is, you can read too much into it. Some interpretations are better than others for very simple reasons that they are more faithful to the original structure.
 
 The accessibility of the Bible is its downfall though, as that accessibility leads to lazy thinking and so it has a tendency to promote dogmatism on issues of doctrine rather than critical discussion thanks to the ancilliary misconception that because the Bible points to Truth that it is Truth.
